There are many questions around contact tracing apps, and I'll try to address some of them in this pinned comment. What's presented is, in essence, the DP-3T algorithm, but needless to say it's a much-simplified version, so most security-related questions can be answered by going to https://github.com/DP-3T and reading the full details. For example, if you're thinking that when Bob's phone recognizes some signals in the hospital's database, it can deduce when Bob met with the someone now known to be sick by looking at where that message shows up on its "What I heard" list, you may be interested to learn how the full details of how these ids are generated and uploaded don't quite make that as possible as it would be for the simplified version outlined in Nicky's post.

One of the biggest concerns is over the efficacy of Bluetooth systems like this. For example, false positives due to signals shared through apartment walls, and false negatives due to touching a shared surface without ever being near someone. No one claims that these will catch all contacts, but the goal is to have a system more scalable than in-person interviews, and what you need is for R to stay consistently below 1, not to catch all cases. Any serious plans for reopening including a system like this also would include other practices driving this reproductive number down, like mask-wearing and distancing where possible. Also, to the accuracy concerns, it seems worth mentioning that at least one person I know is working on https://www.novid.org/ which incorporates ultrasound to get a better sense of proximity.

Many government-issued contact-tracing apps do use GPS in some way, so you'd want to stay informed about whatever specific system is being advertised to you. The purpose of Nicky's post is to make clear that contact tracing does not imply location tracking. If people (or governments) really want to use GPS based contact tracing too, there's no reason you can't have both. But if you're in a country where people can choose to opt-in, you won't be including people who are concerned about privacy.

As to the status of the Google/Apple system, the first phase of their plan involved putting out an API that developers can use to build apps according to these standards, which is now done. The second phase will involve doing something built into the phone's OS, which people can opt in to. For my part, I think the most plausible scenario where we have mass adoption comes something in the OS like this.

From what I can see, the apps act independently of each other, so how do the devs make sure every code sent by every phone is unique?

It also relies on voluntary quarantine for contact tracing, which is a bit idealistic to say the least.

There are a couple of problems.
1. Phones are not ever directly connected to one another, rather they are connected to a cell tower. Opening up the phone to be directly connected too by any phone opens up a number of security problems. Therefore, you would need a server to store all of the phones location data to find who is within proximity in order to transfer the string, defeating the purpose of privacy.
2. Phones don't always have accurate location data. Phones will often be off by some region of error. Therefore, just by driving through the neighborhood could cause the app to think that every house driven by is a potential contact. It would be difficult without a server to isolate errors and maintain privacy.

This idea, while good, would only work if you used a passive token (specialized electronic device), maybe instituted by the hospitals, that you carried around with you that only had the string and some RF based communication that only communicated with the token.

One easy to foresee problem with contact tracing is that most presymptomatic infected people are not highly contagious. From contact tracing studies, we know that 80% of infections are caused by less than 10% of infected individuals. Furthermore being in close contact to someone wearing a mask blocking their respiratory droplets is significantly less risky than if they weren't wearing a mask. The result is that contact-tracing apps will likely provide so many false-positive exposures that people will quickly learn to ignore the warnings. If not just the presence of the virus could be assessed, but also the mask-wearing habbits and quantitatively measuring infectious viral load and other parameters predicting infectiousness, false positive warnings could be significantly reduced.

Sorry, I don't buy it. It appears to me that the Nicky Case examples rest on logical fallacies. The models, and explanations, rest on the presumption that achieving R<1 by isolating symptomatic infections will 'eliminate' Covid-19. At best this is a temporary situation since there will always be someone who is totally asymptomatic, who has not been identified, still in the population at large, infecting people, which will simply restart the logistical growth curve.
The only way to actually 'stop' Covid-19 is through true herd immunity and that will only happen through the spread of infections, either naturally or via vaccines which don't yet exist (and are likely to be on the order of 50% effective when provided).
Contact tracing is only going to extend the time it takes to reach true herd immunity.
Also, it is apparent from multiple tests, that the presence of Covid antibodies is already found in a significant fraction of the population (20% of NYC residents in late April, 10% of Boston residents in late May). This would imply that the risk of serious illness is much lower than the 5% number stated by Mr. Salathe and Mr. Case.
NYC is home to 8.3 million, suggesting that roughly 1.66 million have already been infected resulting in fewer than 21,000 deaths (1.26%). However, NYC estimates (probably low) that 25% of deaths have been in nursing homes, meaning that <1% of the remaining infected population has succumbed. (I won't even go into the likely over-reporting of covid-19 caused deaths)
The borderline hysteria over avoiding covid-19 seems to be based on equating becoming infected with inescapable death. In truth, non-nursing home people catching covid-19 have a >99% chance of surviving.
I don't understand why contact tracing is needed, much less why we are destroying our main street economy by locking everyone in their homes. The sooner true herd immunity is reached, the sooner covid-19 will become a memory.

ok, 2:40 in, it's clear that this compromises on privacy.
The very end goal of contact tracing, that you know who you've been in contact with, reveals a lot about where you've been and when. Let's think of a trivial case. There are sufficiently high number of people who's locations we do know of (either because they decided to share voluntarily or because they were persuaded by enough money for example. Their exact location could be recorded by a companion app for example), then by knowing exactly whom you've been in contact with we will know exactly where you've been, and when.
The case is still somewhat true when the number of people we can track is limited. In general, if you are in such a program, your privacy being protected depends on everybody else protecting theirs. Now imagine if people are offered, say, free wifi, or a free drink, for their current location as well as their contact list, now imagine how many people would take that offer. Doesn't have to be a significant proportion of the population mind you, just need to be enough.
There's no such thing as anonymous data. That's why the census have to fudge their data before publishing, and they can't just publish everything etc. I'd go as far as to say "anonymous data" is oxymoronic.

This has many pitfalls, some shared with location based (but still privacy protecting) solutions, some not:
- No results for beyond the time you installed the app. Location tracking can go beyond this, back to any time point. You can't go and tell doctors to install "hey try this new privacy preserving location tracking". This lack of immediate reward will basically make it have terrible distribution, and not enough people will use it in any given area to make it work.
- The 5 min window of shared secrets + radius of transmission are both heuristics, which can be tweaked with location-shared but not with this. (The duration can still be tweaked though)
- All hospitals must report the same standard, as well as account for testing specificity, sensitivity.
- Self reported minor symptoms have no scope in this, as it currently stands (but could be added easily)

One example of privacy preserving location tracking is with homomorphic encryption.

There are several things that must happen at the same time for contract tracing to respect privacy:
1. No unencrypted storage. (Otherwise whoevery controls the storage device has full access).
2. No cryptographic backdoors for anyone, not even emergency services.
3. No enforceable authentication of key or data release (like biometrics), unless it can be turned off.
4. No names, IMEI, SIM ID or other identifiable data at all. Apps only communicate with each other whether you had contact and whether some contact was infected. You are responsible to act on it yourself.
Does that sound unreasonable? Well it does sound improbable to me, at least. But sacrifice any of those means full disclosure, even if not of the whole dataset at once, so in principle. I think authorities will want something enforceable, and I kind of understand that, but that requirement will immediately kill privacy, however many people, without any doubt, will try to make it appear otherwise.

I appreciate the intent behind the video, but there's a lot more to tracking apps than this, they need to be looked at very closely to truly understand their privacy implications.

A lot of the existing contact tracing apps broadcast bluetooth messages in such a way, that if you can observe the phone over time with multiple bluetooth receivers, you can track its movement. This sort of technology is already common in places like malls and shopping centres. Another important flaw with many of the existing apps is that they broadcast the device model name without encryption, which opens up potential stalking and home safety issues: if you know where a person lives and the model of their phone, you can determine whether they're home or not by listening for tracer app transmissions.

There are also serious questions about whether the bluetooth approach even works (raised in part by the engineers behind the bluetooth spec). These are relatively low power signals, the received signal strength is used to infer the distance between the devices, and the signal strength depends on factors like the shape of the space the devices are in (which affects the paths that radio emissions can take) and whether there are any radio absorbent objects between the two devices (most notably, the water in your own body will absorb radio in the microwave range used by bluetooth and wifi). Bluetooth radio also goes clean through walls and glass, so you run the risk of false contacts from your neighbours (if in an apartment building) or the folks you were stuck in that traffic jam with. There's also a major question around false negatives: most tracking apps consider you to have been "in contact" with another after spending 15 minutes together, but you could very easily spend a brief moment near a contagious person running the app.

All this, and we haven't gotten to the wider social issues, such as the false sense of security that some might derive from carrying an app that is advertised as "protecting them", and normalizing the collection of your close contacts by government apps.

The approach of bluetooth contact tracing apps is a bit half baked, and the potential negative long term consequences are large. We've barely begun to have this conversation. I find these apps very, very hard to recommend.

You know, as soon as I heard that this is possible, I figured it would have to do with phones locally checking for other phones, and I thought up an algorithm that is very similar to this:
So let’s say Alice, Bob, and Charlie have installed the contact tracer. All of these phones will periodically broadcast messages with unique IDs (like the random gibberish). While it broadcasts messages, it will also listen for messages from other phones, such as Bob’s and Charlie’s. When any of these phone receives such a message, it will broadcast it back out, as well as noting that it recently received that message. This way, the phones will keep bouncing the message back and forth.
Let’s say Bob leaves after 5 minutes; his phone will stop receiving the bounced message, so it discards it, and nothing happens. But Alice and Bob stay close together for an extended period of time. After their phones have bounced the message back and forth for a certain period of time, they will both “lock in” the message, and store it as a contact.
A day later, Alice falls ill and tests positive. She uses something like the one-time password to upload her locked-in messages to a server, which Bob and Charlie’s phones check in with every so often. Since Bob locked in the message from Alice (and some others, depending on how long they were in together), his phone will notice the message Alice uploaded matches one of his, and will warn him. However, Charlie’s phone discarded the message and do not lock it in, so it will not notify him.

So basically, it’s like the one here, except instead of looking for several random messages received in a row to notify a contact, it uses one message bounced back and forth a bunch of times. Does that sound like there would be any security issues not associated with what is described in the video?

From NyTeknik (a Swedish tech newspaper):
Swedish bluetooth inventor denounces contact tracking with bluetooth

There are many disadvantages to this method. One of them is that bluetooth has never been developed to make any accurate distance estimates. There is thus a risk that the system will produce false positive or false negative results.
Now Sven Mattisson, one of the men behind the original bluetooth standard, says he shares that assessment.

- In the way that many BLE devices (BLE is the abbreviation for bluetooth low energy) are designed, the RSSI value (RSSI stands for received signal strength indication and is a measure of the strength of a received radio signal) can be quite coarse and not well calibrated, says Mattisson to the site The Intercept.
- And in addition to this RSSI uncertainty, there will be variations in path losses. If there is an obstacle, such as a human body, then there may be a weakening of 70 dB at a distance of 1 meter, while in an open area it may correspond to 10 meters. Exact numbers vary with objects, signal reflections and so on, says Sven Mattisson.

One way to get around this is to use additional positioning techniques, such as triangulation. But then, on the other hand, the user's privacy risks being compromised, which is one of the reasons why the choice fell on bluetooth from the beginning.

Well, nice to see an attempt to tackle some serious issues, but there are some issues that it might not work at all to prevent the second wave.

1. Accessibility: This assumes at least 60% of population has phone AND installed the phone AND have it running at the time. While this seems easy to achieve for us who constantly use phone, it might not be if we include elderly population who are not familiar with such technology, and those who has antique phone that has been around them for 10 yrs or so.

2. Civility: This also assumes that people would voluntarily obey quarantine if they got contact with someone with the virus. Unfortunately, one must assume the worst of humanity exists out there, and they are quite large in number. For example, there were some incidents of quarantine breach in South Korea; people who should've been in quarantine for 14 days just...go out and meet people and go to densely populated areas, because, people who think lock-downs are against their liberty would think the same for the quarantine, too. To prevent this, law enforcement should be in place to make sure they are quarantined, otherwise R would not decrease at all despite of these apps. Moreover, those who break quarantine commonly leave their phone in their home and roam around without it, since the phone has your Geo info regardless of the app they installed, and they could be used against them in court for breaking quarantine. In short, the most infectious people might not be carrying their phone at all, making that 60% criteria less realistic.

So, it sounds pretty unrealistic to me for this to work at all, at least in its current form. There are some ways of tackling this problem, such as giving out devices designed just for this purpose to a lot of people, but at some point this requires involvement of the government to the level some might feel uncomfortable. So, while I think this "invention" has its merits and definitely would improve how we deal with these kind of situation without violating the privacy in the future, we might need to accept that right now it's either privacy invasion or herd immunity, and start discussing what'd be "acceptable" amount of privacy invasion, just like how we discuss how much tax we pay or how we do the military service.

And as a side note, please ponder on the following question: if we cannot entrust our information to the government in fear of big brother situation, that means you don't have any safeguard for such information, and doesn't that mean that we are already living in such environment? I am not saying you should forfeit your privacy willingly. I'm saying that if you think you fear such situation, which I believe is not an unfounded fear, it is likely that your privacy might already be compromised, the politicians in your country are screwed up, and you need to act up. That's a wake-up call, and you have a system to fix.

Its worth mentioning that this is not how all of the apps work. Specifically, the apps in Singapore and Australia use the same core technique for tracing (sending random bits of gibberish to people nearby) but they have a centralised system allocating those bits of gibberish to each device rather than the devices generating them themselves (decentralised). This seems to be done done primarily so that the Government have statistics on who is actively using the app, because if your phone doesn't download the gibberish on a particular day, they know that you aren't actively using it.

For this to be true, the code the Doctor gives out must also be random and not connected to the patient records.

If the doctor notes on his chart that he sent a code and the generation of that code is also recorded, then it is easy to correlate patient records with the code and therefore the random codes a person sent.

Once the doctor gives you an anti-spamming code and you upload all your contact "codes" you must trust that the "anti-spamming code" and your ID are never tied together, though that could occur since the doctor knows them both and presumably transfers the person's ID code to the hospital where you upload your data.
If you have contact codes of others stored before you become infectious, those people will appear to be possibly infected.
How many infections will arise from people who don't have the app or upload their data because they never get tested. Today nobody is tested unless they get sick enough.

These apps have significant drawbacks - they can record "contact" even when there's a physical barrier between the people. So to counteract this possibility they must not only inform user that "you were in contact and must self-quarantine", they must be very specific e.g. "on Tuesday between 14:00-14:20 you received 3 messages from a person that's now infected". So that the receiver can evaluate how dangerous was their exposure at that time - were they in the crowded bus at the time, or waiting in socially distanced queue. And now you see another drawback of such app - users should be allowed to use their own judgement of the risk.

Some sort of simple wire-based transfer (like an old skool serial port) could be used and readers could be installed at various locations where privacy sensitive users could upload their data - or even upload their data via someone else phone used as a proxy (someone with fewer concerns about privacy?). Of course - these locations could also be monitored - the infamous analog hole - so privacy isn't perfect.


Whenever I think about this stuff (I'm in tech, but not a privacy expert) - I get a headache - privacy starts to look like turtles all the way down.. very difficult and usually, it seems, the cryptography is not the weakest link.



PS. The hardware design and implementation must also be open (like the software) - so that it can be reviewed for security.


PPS. don't mean to be overly negative or argumentative - I supportive of the system described in the video - with the right supporting systems outside the application itself. Hopefully it will have enough privacy for enough people to use it. I would probably use it as described with the caveats of not having to login to some centralized system (i.e. medical provider and yes, that includes, my google login).

Scrolling through the comments, I find that many people who are skeptical of this technology are missing what this method is trying to prevent and what it doesn't. This way of doing contact tracking has two main advantages: it doesn't track your location, and it also doesn't even track your contacts. The former is self explanatory, but the latter is where it gets interesting. If Alice is infected and uploads her data to a server, no information actually leaves her phone. Even if there is a security breach, the only piece of information the attacker can obtain is that Alice has the virus. Keep in mind here, that that information has to be collected and stored anyway, if we want to contain the virus, whether there is an Anti-Corona-App or not. Even more importantly, if Bob goes to check for contacts, he does not send any information to the database at all. So if you are not infected, you are not giving up any data whatsoever.

The one thing the App will not, and in fact cannot, prevent is that when you get the notification that you've had contact with a positive case, you might be able to deduce who that might be. But this is, as shown above, not a problem of the app, but rather of the situation at hand. If you were found in contact with an infected person via an interview of said person, you could just as well deduce who that might have been.

So if we want to contain the virus at all, there can always be personal data spilled, in one form ore another. This idea for an app is, simply put, the most efficient and secure way we have.

There has been an argument over one aspect here in Germany and many other european countries. INACCURATE SHORT VERSION:

In the simplest implementation (and the whitepaper has mitigations for this) we have two lists of random Numbers (representation doesn't matter) and we need to bring them together. One distributed on everyone's phone ("What I heard") and one somewhere with the state (List of Numbers sent by the infected). And here's the problem: By themselves, these numbers are useless and don't contain any personal information. If you have both, however, and you kept track of whom you got each number from, similar numbers correspond to people having met. This is a sort of social graph that (as many privacy focused organizations argue) should not exist in a democracy.
So if you want to prevent an evil state from being able to get to know this graph, you must not send everyone's list to the state. Instead, you could hand out the state list to everyone.
There are however problems with that too. E.g. by keeping track of who I met when and the numbers they sent out, I can later look up who got infected. That's medical data being leaked, even if only for some people at a time instead of a population.

There are mitigations for both problems. Some useful, some not. I just wanted to mention that there is more to learn and I can highly recommend further reading. Some sources to start include the DP-3T whitepaper or the material by PEPP-PT.

Hello 3blue1brown, long time subscriber and I love your videos. However you've made several critical errors in your assessment here. As a security researcher, I'd be happy to talk to you more about this, but a brief summary can be found below;

First of all, the concern people have isn't generally that other people with the app (Bob) can infer their GPS location. That's what your video describes the protection through obfuscation against. The concern is around that central tabulary, and it takes literally one string of data (the device ID) being leaked through the application, which could happen in a later update and doesn't have to be currently present in the code, to make Alice and her network of contacts trackable (definitely and trivially by 'Big Brother' but also by any bad actor). More concerning is that, from a 'Big Brother' standpoint, there are innumerable ways of making that happen without even needing to modify the app itself.

Again, I'd be happy to go into detail with you on this, but what I want you to understand is that these apps as designed in no way protect privacy, and do constitute a substantial overreach. The timing corresponding to an extension of the warrantless surveillance act is also of concern for privacy advocates.

Please feel free to reach out to me, I'd welcome the opportunity to repay the gift of knowledge by teaching you something for once.

There is a huge difference between whether there are no privacy issues in theory, and the actual implementation. Initially, our government wanted to have apps like that as well, keeping privacy in mind. When the first designs were presented, journalists, security experts and IT specialists were having a field day: none of the dozens of presented apps was safe. They bled sensitive information by the bucket. Government has dropped plans of creating such an app like a hot potato (or at least, has become very, very quiet about it).

Also, what any such app will do, is track people, whether it's movement, or contacts. That is, at best, only a lousy proxy of what you really want: track the spread of the virus. The virus can easily spread with contacts much shorter than five minutes, but also, it doesn't have to be transmitted if you're staying "near" someone for a long time. My neighbour is physically near to me, but the virus isn't likely to pass through a brick wall. But the person in the shop who bumps into me, can transmit the virus. Which means, any such apps will give a high number of false positives, both positives and negatives. And the false negatives will be a problem, it will give people a false sense of security; they may start doing things they ought not be doing.

One point that is never talked about is the number of "false-positive" contacts. Two phones can share bluetooth signals even if the persons are not in contact and at risk of transmitting the virus, through a thin wall for example.
